docs.snippet: The final full day of campaigning was a blur of rallies, plane rides and meet-and-greet encounters for the candidates, and at every step of the way four New York Times reporters were there to chronicle the hectic final push. The following are disp...
docs.lead_paragraph: The final full day of campaigning was a blur of rallies, plane rides and meet-and-greet encounters for the candidates, and at every step of the way four New York Times reporters were there to chronicle the hectic final push. The following are dispatches from Elisabeth Bumiller on the McCain campaign, Jeff Zeleny on the Obama campaign, John M. Broder on the Biden campaign, and Julie Bosman on the Palin campaign. 8:40 a.m.
docs.abstract: Chronology of activities of John McCain, Sarah Palin, Barack Obama and Joseph Biden on final hectic day on campaign trail before presidential election; photos (M)

headline.main: Minute by Minute, a Final Hectic Day on the Campaign Trail

docs.snippet: Is it significant that Indiana has not yet been called for McCain?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Could Obama really win the Hoosier State? Indiana is a reliably Republican state during presidential elections, so it's a bad omen for John McCain that he's not winning the state handily enough for the networks to call it. But can Obama really win it? Nate Silver, the math wiz at FiveThirtyEight.com, looks at the numbers trailing in from some Indiana counties:
docs.abstract: Is it significant that Indiana has not yet been called for McCain?

docs.snippet: A magnificent victory for Barack Obama. And bear in mind that the campaign, in its final stages, was really about different philosophies of governing. This wasn't like the 2004 campaign, which was essentially fought over fake issues - Bush running...
docs.lead_paragraph: A magnificent victory for Barack Obama. And bear in mind that the campaign, in its final stages, was really about different philosophies of governing. This wasn't like the 2004 campaign, which was essentially fought over fake issues -- Bush running on national security and social issues, then claiming that he had a mandate to privatize Social Security. In this election, Obama proudly stood up for progressive values and the superiority of progressive policies; John McCain, in return, denounced him as a socialist, a redistributor. And the American people rendered their verdict.
docs.abstract: A magnificent victory for Barack Obama. And bear in mind that the campaign, in its final stages, was really about different philosophies of governing. This wasn't like the 2004 campaign, which was essentially fought over fake issues - Bush running on national security and social issues, then claiming that he had a mandate to privatize [...]
